chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of suspected Osgood-Schlatter disease
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with suspected Osgood-Schlatter disease, and when to refer.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 6 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with suspected Osgood-Schlatter disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Explain the diagnosis and signpost to sources of information:
    • Patient information is available from the Association of Paediatric Chartered Physiotherapists ‘Osgood Schlatters’ Disease’.
  • Advise the person or their parents/carers that symptoms usually resolve over time.
    • In most cases this will be within a few months but in some symptoms may persist longer.
    • For more information, see the section on Prognosis.
  • Advise about options that may provide pain relief, if needed. These include:
    • Analgesia — offer paracetamol and/or a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) if there are no contraindications. For more information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
    • Intermittent application of ice packs over the tibial tuberosity (10–15 minutes up to three times a day, including after exercise).
    • Protective knee pads, which may be useful to relieve pain on kneeling.
  • Advise the person or their parents/carers that they will not usually need to stop all sporting activity, and a reduction in activity may be sufficient to control pain.
    • If the person is able to exercise with only minimal symptoms advise them to continue taking exercise but to seek advice if symptoms worsen.
    • If the person is having difficulty tolerating their usual exercise, advise them to modify exercise for a limited period. The amount of exercise modification needed to decrease symptoms to an acceptable level will vary from person to person, depending on symptom severity and the response to treatment. Strategies may include:
      • Reducing exercise duration, frequency, or intensity.
      • Changing the type of exercise to activities that avoid or limit the amount of running and jumping (for example swimming or cycling).
      • As symptoms decrease, gradually increasing exercise as tolerated.
    • If the person cannot tolerate a modified exercise programme advise them to avoid activities that provoke pain for a limited period until symptoms decrease. As symptoms decrease, advise introducing low-impact quadriceps exercises before gradually increasing the intensity of exercise.
      • Options include multiple isometric quadriceps contractions, straight-leg raises, or cross-training with activities such as cycling or swimming. Offer a patient information leaflet about stretching exercises, such as that published by the Victorian Paediatric Orthopaedic Network, if appropriate.
      • If symptoms remain settled, advise them to gradually increase the intensity of exercise and to combine with stretching of the quadriceps and hamstrings.
      • If symptoms recur, advise them to stop exercises or reduce their intensity. The person can gradually re-establish exercise or increase exercise intensity on the basis of symptoms.
  • Advise the person on the importance of preventative strategies such as regular quadriceps and hamstring stretching and cross-training.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Providing advice on prognosis
  • The recommendation to advise the person on prognosis is based on expert opinion in review articles [Gholve, 2007; Weiler, 2011; Patel, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020].
  • As treatment can lead to an interruption of regular training schedules for several months — counselling (for competitive sports in particular) is essential [Ladenhauf, 2020].
Advice on pain relief strategies
  • The recommendations on offering analgesia, applying ice packs, and using protective knee pads are based on expert opinion in review articles [Gholve, 2007; Weiler, 2011; Vaishya, 2016; Circi, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020].
Exercise modification and stretching exercises
  • The recommendation to provide advice on restriction or adjustment of pain-producing exercise is based on expert opinion in review articles [Weiler, 2011; Circi, 2017; Patel, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020] that in general emphasize the general health benefits of physical activity in childhood and beyond, and advise continuing activity below the threshold that induces pain.
  • The recommendations on exercise modification regimes and the value of muscle stretching exercises to help maintain knee stability and reduce or prevent muscle shortening around the knee are based on expert opinion in review articles [Gholve, 2007; Domingues, 2013; Patel, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020], a systematic review [Cairns, 2018], cohort studies [Nakase, 2015; Rathleff, 2020], and a cross-sectional study [De Lucena, 2011].
    • One prospective cohort study [Rathleff, 2020] of a 12-week intervention consisting of a temporary reduction in sports activity and knee exercises (static holds and bridges to avoid the loss of muscle strength) in weeks 1–4 followed by knee strengthening exercises (progressing from isometric holds to lunges) and gradual return-to-sport in weeks 5–12 for adolescents with Osgood-Schlatter disease (n = 51) found that:
      • After 12 weeks, 80% reported a successful outcome in that they felt that knee symptoms had improved or much improved (this increased to 90% at 12 months).
      • At 12 weeks, 16% returned to playing sport, which increased to 67% at 6 months and 69% at 12 months.
    • Shortening of the rectus femoris may affect the biomechanical function of the knee in activities such as walking, running, deceleration, and jumping [De Lucena, 2011]  [Domingues, 2013; Nakase, 2015]. A prospective cohort study (n = 150) of adolescent male football players found that increased quadriceps femoris muscle tightness and strength during knee extension, and flexibility of the hamstring muscles were risk factors for developing Osgood-Schlatter disease. The authors conclude that proactive preventative measures should be taken including quadriceps stretching [Nakase, 2015].
  • The recommendation on preventative strategies including stretching and cross-training with low-impact sports such as cycling or swimming is based on expert opinion in review articles [Whitmore, 2013; Circi, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020] and a cohort study [Nakase, 2015].
    • Exercises include hamstring stretches on the wall, standing calf stretches as well as quadriceps and rectus femoris stretches along with exercises to enhance knee stabilization and hip movement including side-lying leg lifts and clam exercises [Ladenhauf, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage people with persistent symptoms?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For people whose symptoms do not improve, or worsen, despite appropriate management:
    • Reassess the possible cause of knee pain and refer for specialist assessment to a paediatrician or orthopaedic surgeon if there is diagnostic uncertainty.
    • Consider referral to a physiotherapist, who may provide additional advice on stretching, strengthening, and reducing muscle imbalance of the quadriceps, hamstrings, calf muscles, and ileotibial band.
  • For people whose symptoms persist into adulthood:
    • Refer for specialist assessment to an orthopaedic surgeon if symptoms are significantly affecting the person's functioning — in severe cases surgical treatment may be considered.
    • Advise that protective knee pads may be useful to relieve pain on kneeling.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Reassessing the possible cause of knee pain
  • The recommendation to exclude an alternative cause for knee pain is based on expert opinion in review articles [Gholve, 2007; Weiler, 2011].
  • With appropriate management, symptoms of Osgood-Schlatter disease are expected to improve in about 90% of people. Persistent or worsening symptoms may indicate another underlying cause for symptoms [Gholve, 2007].
Referral to physiotherapy
  • The recommendation to consider referral to physiotherapy for exercise advice is based on expert opinion in review articles [Weiler, 2011; Whitmore, 2013; Ladenhauf, 2020].
  • Physical therapy is essential and should generally include core stability, thorough mobilization, hamstring stretches on the wall, standing calf stretches, quadriceps stretches, and rectus femoris stretches; exercises to enhance knee stabilization and hip movement (such as side-lying leg lifts and clam exercises) should also be added [Ladenhauf, 2020].
Advice on knee pads
  • The recommendation on offering knee pads to relieve pain on kneeling is based on expert opinion in review articles  [Gholve, 2007; Weiler, 2011].
Referral to orthopaedics if symptoms are significantly affecting functioning
  • The recommendation to refer to an orthopaedic surgeon if symptoms are affecting the person's functioning is based on expert opinion in review articles [Gholve, 2007; Weiler, 2011; Circi, 2017; Patel, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020].
  • In severe cases, surgical measures (such as excision of an ossicle and/or free cartilaginous material) may be considered in adults who remain symptomatic despite conservative measures [Gholve, 2007; Patel, 2017; Ladenhauf, 2020].
  • Corticosteroid injections are not recommended because of an increased risk of atrophy and rupture of the patellar tendon [Ladenhauf, 2020].
